sourceClass: Medical Devices, Medical and Pharmaceutical Regulation
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Medical
Devices Daily \-- Investigators publish new report on Right Ventricular.
According to news reporting originating from Middlesex, United Kingdom, by
NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Milrinone is a phosphodiesterase III
inhibitor used as an inodilator in patients with right ventricular (RV)
failure. Oral milrinone may offer an alternative to patients with refractory
RV dysfunction supported with left ventricular assist devices (LVAD)."

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Harefield Hospital,
"We reviewed all patients supported on an LVAD commenced on oral milrinone for
a refractory right ventricular failure who were maintained using therapeutic
drug monitoring in the community (range 100-300 ng/ml). Available haemodynamic
data and outcomes were assessed. Seven patients (Median Age 50 (IQR 48-54),
Male 6/7) on chronic LVAD support with refractory RV failure, were commenced
on oral Milrinone for persistently raised Pulmonary Vascular Resistance (PVR)
or recurrent episodes of decompensated heart failure. The median duration of
milrinone therapy was 117(IQR 59-221) days. Outpatient monitoring of milrinone
levels was feasible and showed overall Median level was 175(111-256) ng/ml.
There were no adverse events related to milrinone and in particular, there
were no arrhythmias recorded. One patient died due to worsening heart failure;
two patients were transplanted but one died during the post-op period. Of the
surviving patients, matched right heart catheterisation data were available
for 3 patients (see table) which showed some evidence of improved PVR and
Cardiac Index (CI). In this limited cohort, oral milrinone appears to be
tolerated, safe and feasible to maintain appropriate therapeutic levels in
this population in the community."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This therapy may offer
additional cardiovascular support for patients deteriorating on maximal LVAD
support who are not immediate candidates for cardiac transplantation."

For more information on this research see: An Initial Experience from a Single
Centre with Oral Milrinone in Patients Supported with a Left Ventricular
Assist Device. _The Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation_ ,
2020;39(4):S448. _The Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation_ can be
contacted at: Elsevier Science Inc, 360 Park Ave South, New York, NY
10010-1710, USA.

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting G. Giblin, Transplant, Harefield Hospital, Middlesex, UK.
Additional authors for this research include C. Butcher, A. Morley-Smith, P.
Ly, G. O'Carrol, O. Dar, F.R. Gil, A. Simon and H. Lyster.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.healun.2020.01.270>. This DOI is a link to an
online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be
your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the _The Journal of Heart and Lung
Transplantation_ is: Elsevier Science Inc, 360 Park Ave South, New York, NY
10010-1710, USA.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Reports on Right Ventricular Findings from Harefield Hospital Provide New Insights (An Initial Experience from a Single Centre with Oral Milrinone in Patients Supported with a Left Ventricular Assist Device): Right Ventricular
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Medical Devices Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Right Ventricular. According to news reporting originating from Middlesex, United Kingdom, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “Milrinone is a phosphodiesterase III inhibitor used as an inodilator in patients with right ventricular (RV) failure. Oral milrinone may offer an alternative to patients with refractory RV dysfunction supported with left ventricular assist devices (LVAD).”

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Harefield Hospital, “We reviewed all patients supported on an LVAD commenced on oral milrinone for a refractory right ventricular failure who were maintained using therapeutic drug monitoring in the community (range 100-300 ng/ml). Available haemodynamic data and outcomes were assessed. Seven patients (Median Age 50 (IQR 48-54), Male 6/7) on chronic LVAD support with refractory RV failure, were commenced on oral Milrinone for persistently raised Pulmonary Vascular Resistance (PVR) or recurrent episodes of decompensated heart failure. The median duration of milrinone therapy was 117(IQR 59-221) days. Outpatient monitoring of milrinone levels was feasible and showed overall Median level was 175(111-256) ng/ml. There were no adverse events related to milrinone and in particular, there were no arrhythmias recorded. One patient died due to worsening heart failure; two patients were transplanted but one died during the post-op period. Of the surviving patients, matched right heart catheterisation data were available for 3 patients (see table) which showed some evidence of improved PVR and Cardiac Index (CI). In this limited cohort, oral milrinone appears to be tolerated, safe and feasible to maintain appropriate therapeutic levels in this population in the community.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “This therapy may offer additional cardiovascular support for patients deteriorating on maximal LVAD support who are not immediate candidates for cardiac transplantation.”

For more information on this research see: An Initial Experience from a Single Centre with Oral Milrinone in Patients Supported with a Left Ventricular Assist Device. The Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation, 2020;39(4):S448. The Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation can be contacted at: Elsevier Science Inc, 360 Park Ave South, New York, NY 10010-1710, USA.

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting G. Giblin, Transplant, Harefield Hospital, Middlesex, UK. Additional authors for this research include C. Butcher, A. Morley-Smith, P. Ly, G. O’Carrol, O. Dar, F.R. Gil, A. Simon and H. Lyster.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.healun.2020.01.270. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the The Journal of Heart and Lung Transplantation is: Elsevier Science Inc, 360 Park Ave South, New York, NY 10010-1710, USA.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
